text: Thats really helpful thank you :simple_smile: the stuff we'll be working on is a mixture of projects including a professional short film so that we have shots that we can put on our reels. Im unsure of what should be shown in a reel for fx artist or even where exactly fx fits into the pipeline which is why i wasnt sure what it would be good to know :simple_smile:

Ah sure...i can go into that. FX basically sits before lighting and compositing. We take (depending on the task) what modeling/anim/tracking/layout gives us and then place our effects in that environment. Some companies skip lighting and fx just renders their elements and they go straight to comp. Otherwise lighting-department would handle that for us (like they do where i'm currently at - Framestore)

I think fx-reels vary quite widely in what people decide to show in the beginning of their career. I think it basically comes to being "test shots"...some copy a scene from a movie that has interesting fx (spaceship landing, kicking up dust etc for example), you could shoot a little thing on your phone/camera rented from the uni, track that footage and then place some cool fx in there; another thing would be to code together a little tool that automates certain things fx-wise (distributing things over a landscape for example). Or it could be any combination of the above :wink:. The obvious one is of course shots and breakdowns from your final project...that probably counts the most for first applciations
